On Thu, 2003-07-31 at 09:47, Adam Jack wrote:

> You guys all seem very caught up on decoupling, and I'll acknowledge I am
> far from an OO purist, I have a job to do & I write code. I attempt to write
> standalone (decoupled) classes, I attempt to make them have well structed
> "APIs" but at the end of the day, if A uses B (however implemented, and
> however used -- aggregation, subclassing, command/messaging paradigms,
> whatever) *for whatever reason* then surely for A to work, B ought work? If
> B fail a test then it has broken the contracts the tests assert, so it's
> behaviours must be deemed unknown. I B is unknown, I could argue (a user
> choice, on a per case basis) that it isn't worth knowing what the outcome of
> A's results test are. If they pass, then perhaps those tests don't cover
> enough. If they fail, isn't quite likely because B failed and what A relied
> upon is bogus?

I think what everyone's trying to tell you is that this issue of
dependencies in your tests is a code smell, and though you may be used
to doing it this way, there MIGHT be a healthy way to decouple your code
so that this issue doesn't persist.


> >	Maybe the direct dependency on the collection object is the problem in the
> >	first place. You could take your problem with many test cases failing at
> once
> >	as a strong hint to remove this direct dependency. If your collection
> object,
> >	however, is so low level that a direct dependency does not hurt then it
> >	should be very very stable; the probability that it fails in a fundamental
> way,
> >	which makes lots of other tests fail too, is very low.
> 
> There might be gold in that statement. You are saying that failures can
> propagate (as I say) but that as you go up the stack the chance for
> catastrophic failure ought not be there. I wonder if the result I am looking
> for is better suited in the case of catastrophic failure, not just "some
> obscure failure". That is possible.
> 
> With this observation, maybe what I am asking for is too fuzzy. I think that
> code uses code (however you structure it) and much as there ought not be
> dependency on internal, if code breaks is "API agreement" then anything that
> uses that API is in doubt, and not worth testing. Trouble is, I'd not want
> to do this on a "method by method" or "test by test" basics, so I was
> proposing doing it on TestCases. At this level, I can see how it is not fine
> grained enough, and perhaps too fuzzy.

OK Here I can talk about this.   

In my code, if an object I'm working on wants to offer behavior to
others, he first gets an Interface and then I create an interface for
people he works with.  Next I implement those two interfaces.  In order
to test each Implementation, I run a MockObject of the interface not
being tested.  MockObjects don't fail and don't need to be tested.  Each
object can be tested in isolation from the other.  I don't have to worry
about some other class failing, and thus making my test on The other
class suspect. (Psst... Use EasyMock)

My biggest pet peeve in my current job, is a Monster Singleton that's
referred to by static reference EVERYWHERE IN OUR GUI!!!!

Can't test anything, because that singleton is so tightly coupled with
all of the code, and he takes a lot, including a Tomcat server address
(working) in order to do even the slightest thing.  So, my major task at
my work is to slowly but surely reduce the dependencies on this monster,
as I go.  I do it very slowly and by forcing people to work through an
interface instead of directly through him.  I'm still plugging away at
it.   I shall overcome!
